Not sure what to say about this. No doubt that freezing can keep your roasted coffee fresh for longer, but its not freezing the beans in the same way that you are freezing fluids. Coffee has very little fluid or water left in the beans after roasting, so its not really freezing the beans. Aldo those beans are darker roasted, so they are brittle because they have even less water than say, a medium roasted bean or a light roasted bean, thats why they are really brittle.

A lot of very basic mistakes and false advice, like sweetness and bitterness depending on what machine you use to brew the coffee and the temperature of the water? So the type of bean and the type of process, the roast level and the degassing has nothing to do with sweetness and bitterness?

Who in their right mind puts coffee beans in a food processer? That's your culprit right there, friction and heat from the processer, smashing those beans instead of consistently and uniformly grinding the beans is also going to destroy any chance of decent extraction and flavor. They just killed that coffee before they even started.

You guys used pre-cooked coffee beans. Now I'm wondering what would happen if you did those same experiments with uncooked coffee beans and then roasted them. Would that make a difference in the taste? Or would you have to do the process, which you just did on the cooked ones, all over again with the already cooked beans? Would that make a bigger difference or not difference at all?

i think this test needs to be done different. when you cool something that much, then hot water runs over it. it wont heat as much as the room temp beans. different flavour terpenes are drawn out at different temps. the bitter flavor, and dark color is probably drawn out at very hot temps. so i wander if your result would change if you were to cool all the beans , and then let them warm to room temp equally ?. the freeze dried one would probably almost count as being extra roasted . so maybe you could get the same result with just putting them in the oven at freeze dryer warm temps for equal time?. and you should have used 4 coffee makers. because the buildup in the coffee maker itself would possibly have changed the flavors .

I used to work in a plant genomics lab. To extract DNA from samples, I needed to powderize them first. The friction of the grinding process heated up the samples and messed with our results until we did the grinding itself in liquid N2. The sample was in a test tube and the tube was in a metal block sitting in the N2 and we put a micropestle on a drill like a bit and finished it off by hand. You should see if there is a way you can grind the coffee still at temperature without breaking your tech and find out if there is a taste difference.

You were distrot about how your grind didn't turn out all uniform.  Use a burr grinder.  A blades on a chop grinder will hit or miss the bean.  So technically.  You could grind some beans into oblivion and not even touch the rest of them.  Not so with a burr grinder.  Each bean must grind to the same level before it can pass on between the burrs.  Well worth the extra 25% cost.

This one baffles me. Firstly grinding with a conical bur grinder is more fine ground than blade one. Secondly cover must be filtered at 98.3 celcius any lesser will be sour any more will be bitter. 9 grams of coffee to 30ml of water is ideal pour. Then there is 45 degree angle of pour of milk to create a natural swirl. Finally its far too expensive commercially to have dry ice and liquid nitrogen. Not trying to be that guy, but putting the beans in a food processor instead of a bean grinder gives inconsistencies. You need a constant in the bean grind, a more though consistancy in the bean. Chopping coffee beans doesn't release the full flavor. And for a French press, I use medium to small grind. Let it steep with the cover on and press at the surface for about ten minutes, then press. Bout the best cup of coffee you'll have. And the darker the roast, the less caffeine. But you already know this!

Just so you know using a food processor is probably the worst way possible to grind coffee. Also the should have been a blind taste test because it's pretty obvious they left their preconceived notions guide their choices. Still a fun little experiment.

One of the biggest mistakes people make when brewing coffee, they did it right in this video, is thinking that using less coffee grounds will make a better, less bitter, cup of coffee. That's so completely wrong. The less coffee there is to extract the flavors from the more bitter the brew will be. You have to balance it but more is almost always better.

Coffee beans ground in a food processor .... noooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooo. Get a real coffee bean grinder.

Depending on your water, a pinch of baking soda (sodium bicarbonate) will neutralize some of the acid (be careful you don't make it salty).  Secondly, do not leave the hot plate under the coffee on after you brew. It can burn the coffee even when there is still a lot in the pot.  Reheat in the microwave which can also cause the volatile oils to dissipate.  These work for me. Your mileage may vary

You guys definitely need a burr grinder. You can get a conical mill burr grinder for less than $100. Blade grinding coffee beans is notoriously bad for inconsistency and when you’re trying to compare cups of coffee, your results are useless if you’re using a food processor to grind your beans.

Also try pour-over or a Chemex method of brewing and use a gooseneck kettle for goodness sakes. You need complete control to get legitimate results for this experiment, please redo it with my suggestions. (Also, 2 grams of beans per fluid ounce of water.)

I wonder how this'd effect culturing kombucha in coffee? I know you can use coffee instead of tea for that. But will preparation methods done like this affect a fermentation end result?

Might be worth testing. Can avoid variations in the starter culture by just using a lot of starter and splitting it in equal amounts. Should be able to produce all the different methods with no variables in the starter culture. So any differences would be solely from how the coffee was prepared.

I recommend doing a few practice runs first so you avoid tasting the brew multiple times before it's been going on long enough to be perfectly done. Keep the source of the starter the same and the timeframe it's left to ferment for. That'll also help see if it increases or reduces fermentation time needed. All you need a cheesecloth and string and jars and a starter. And of course the coffee and sugar.

Kevin is a former NASA employee that uses US units instead of SI units or metric like the rest of the world (except Liberia and Myanmar). That's how things like the Mars Climate Orbiter get messed up. It went too low and either burned up or went in a trajectory towards the sun, all because the software produced output in non-SI units of pound-force seconds instead of the SI units of newton-seconds.
I'm not saying Kevin did that, he's way too young, but man... Just use celsius for temperature and SI units for everything else like the rest of the world.
